digitalObject.dc:title: Plan of the Plaza Mayor, Mexico City.
digitalObject.dcterms:alternative: Plan of the Templo Mayor, Mexico City
digitalObject.dc:description: This map of Mexico City's Plaza Mayor, dating to 1563, shows a rational urbanism that was well in effect. It depicts a small and quite primitive Cathedral (Mexico's first cathedral) to the north, a canal, dating from the pre-Conquest period, to the south, the first building of the Real y Pontificia Universidad de México behind the cathedral, and the Peal Palacio to the east. The outlined rectangle to the right of the Cathedral is the foundation of the new Cathedral--the cornerstone of which had just been laid the previous. This plan shows how, from the beginning, the Plaza Mayor concentrated the forces of Church, Crown, and commerce in the sacred space once reserved for Aztec ceremonial life.
Current Location: Archivo General de Indias, Seville.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Plazas--Mexico--Mexico City--Designs and plans.
City planning--Mexico--Mexico City.
Historic buildings--Mexico--Mexico City--Designs and plans.
digitalObject.dcadesc:geogname: Plaza de la Constitución (Mexico City, Mexico)

digitalObject.dc:title: Placio de Cortés.
digitalObject.dc:description: This structure preserves the blocky crenellated walls and open Renaissance arcades (one of which now shelters a mural painted in 1930 by Diego Rivera) common to many early civil constructions. This is one of many early civil buildings that still survive and from which we can get some sense of the aesthetics of the structures which used to exist in the center of Mexico City.
Date created: begun in the late 1520s.

digitalObject.dc:title: Interior Courtyard of Placio de Cortés.
digitalObject.dc:description: Interior courtyard of the Palace of Cortes shows the remains of the former pre-Hispanic structure. The main palacio structure preserves the blocky crenellated walls and open Renaissance arcades (one of which now shelters a mural painted in 1930 by Diego Rivera) common to many early civil constructions. This is one of many early civil buildings that still survive and from which we can get some sense of the aesthetics of the structures which used to exist in the center of Mexico City.
Date created: begun in the late 1520s.

digitalObject.dc:title: Casa de Montejo.
digitalObject.dc:description: Built by the son of one of the chief conquistadors, this building features an ornate Mannerist façade and classicizing relief decorations, including portrait busts possibly of the first owner and his wife, mythological figures, and quirky animals. Above the window, the Montejo coat of arms is flanked by gigantic statues of Spanish halberdiers who tower over hairy "wild men" wielding rustic clubs--a symbol of victory over uncivilized or pagan forces, according to medieval Spanish traditions. These sculptures were also meant to evoke the ongoing and brutal conquest of the local Maya. As such, this facade, and others like it, were meant to communicate Renaissance sophistication, martial power and royal or aristocratic authority.

digitalObject.dc:title: Triumph of Love.
digitalObject.dc:description: This wall decoration is from a series of renditions of five of Petrarch's Triumphs, which narrate humanity's victories over earthly passions. These triumphal depictions, commissioned by Tomás de la Plaza, dean of Puebla Cathedral, are derived from a series of Flemish prints by Maarten van Heemskerck from 1562, representing the victories of Time, Death, Love, Chastity, and Fame. The sixth triumph, "Faith," was either not included or does not survive. The one presented here is the Triumph of Love. As a whole, these decorations were meant as a public testimony to the patron's sophisticated Classical learning and humanism, despite Church censorship. Although nothing is known about the painters of these murals, inventive ornamental borders (sometimes called "grotesques") reveal evidence of an indigenous hand, especially as it pertains to the speech scrolls and native animals associated with pre-Hispanic vices and virtues. After centuries hidden by whitewash, the murals in this much-altered building were rediscovered in 1953.
Current Location: Casa del Deán, Puebla, Mexico.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Mural painting and decoration, Mexican--Mexico--Puebla de Zaragoza.
Mural painting and decoration, Colonial--Mexico--Puebla de Zaragoza.

digitalObject.dc:title: The Virgin of the Rosary.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Ortiz, Juan, approximately 1538-
digitalObject.dc:description: One of the few prints produced in New Spain from the 16th century that survive, this hand-colored woodcut, dated 1571, but made the year before, shows the Virgin of the Rosary, patroness of the Dominicans. It was created by Juan Ortiz, a French printmaker who had arrived in New Spain in 1568 as part of the viceroy's entourage. He included a poem as a caption to the print to which the Inquisition accused for its supposed inaccuracy and heresy, and the image was held, and perfectly preserved, in the Inquisition files. The image, perhaps based on a French model, was printed in the Mexico City shop of Pedro Ocharte. Evidence suggests that indigenous assistants added color by using stencils and were employed in framing such prints for sale.
Location Created: Pedro Ocharte, Mexico City.
Current Location: Archivo General de la Nación, Mexico City.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Wood-engraving, Mexican.

digitalObject.dc:title: Saint Christopher with the Christ Child.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Pereyns, Simón, -1589.
digitalObject.dc:description: Painted by Simón Pereyns, one of the three European artists who dominated late 16th century painting in New Spain, this is one of his earliest dated paintings in New Spain. Painted in the "Reformed Mannerist" style, it depicts the giant, Saint Christopher, carrying the Christ Child across a river and was commissioned for an altarpiece in the Mexico City Cathedral. Saint Christopher was of particular interest to the Spanish, who saw their laborious efforts to carry Christianity across the Atlantic reflected in the story of this giant and his holy cargo.
Current Location: Cathedral Metropolitana, Mexico City.
6 ft 5 3/4 x 5 ft 1 in (200 x 155 cm)

digitalObject.dc:title: The Vision of Saint Francis at the Porziuncola.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Echave Orio, Baltasar de, 1558-1623.
digitalObject.dc:description: Painted by Baltasar de Echave Orio, one of the late 16th century European artists who dominated painting in New Spain, this picture depicts a legend concerning Saint Francis. The legend recounts how the saint had a vision of Jesus and Mary at the Porziuncola, a small church outside Assisi, Italy. They granted his request that those who entered the Porziuncola be pardoned their sins. The painting originally formed part of the main retablo at Santiago Tlatelolco. It was influenced by the works of artist Alonso Vázquez and was painted in the Reformed Mannerist style, drawing elements from Spain, Flanders, and Southern Italy. Furthermore, this style balanced a late-Renaissance fascination with distorting space and elongating the human body with Counter-Reformation demands that painting provide clear, direct, and inspirational messages.
Current Location: Museo Nacional de Arte, Mexico City.
Measurements: 8 ft 1/4 in x 5 ft 3 5/8 in ( 244.5 x 161.6 cm)

digitalObject.dc:title: Saints Justus and Pastor.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Juárez, José, 1617-1661.
digitalObject.dc:description: Painted by José Juárez, the finest painter of mid-seventeenth-century Mexico, this painting illustrates the type of religious imagery that perfectly answered the Counter-Reformation call for "decency," i.e. works that were not only spiritually correct but also opulent and inspirational. It depicts the child martyrs Justus and Pastor, beheaded in AD 304 outside the present-day city of Alcalá de Henares, Spain. The painting emphasizes triumph and heroism over suffering, which reflected current doctrinal requirements, inspired by Flemish engravings. The painting may allude to the ornate procession the Pope order in 1567 for the bones return to Alcalá (through decorated cities and past triumphal arches) and reveals the indirect impact of Zurbarán in its finely crafted surfaces, interest in psychology, and complex architectural framework.
Current Location: Museo Nacional de Arte, Mexico City.
Measurements: 12 ft 4 1/2 in x 9 ft 5 1/4 in (377 x 288 cm)

digitalObject.dc:title: The Incredulity of Saint Thomas.
digitalObject.dc:creator: López de Arteaga, Sebastián, 1610-1652.
digitalObject.dc:description: Painted by Sevillian artist Sebastián López de Arteaga, who emigrated from Spain around 1640, this biblical painting is one of the most compelling images from seventeenth-century Mexico. Depicting the doubtful saint Thomas gently touching wound in Jesus's side, the painting has dramatic lighting that seems inspired by the tenebrism of Caravaggio who painted a similar scene in 1600-1601. Unlike Caravaggio, however, Arteaga's painting is less naturalistic and more eclectic, drawing on a variety of Sevillian sources, including the paintings of the young Diego Velásquez.
Current Location: Museo Nacional de Arte, Mexico City.
Measurements: 7 ft 3 3/4 in x 5 ft 1 in (222.9 x 154.9 cm)

digitalObject.dc:title: The Adoration of the Magi.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Echave Rioja, Baltasar de, 1632-1682.
digitalObject.dc:description: This painting, by Baltasar de Echave Rioja, illustrates the impact of Flemish art, and specifically the prints by and beyond Rubens, whose prints may have been given to the artist as specific models. In addition to the prints, this painting shows the influence of a painting on the same theme by Zurbarán. However, Rioja arranged his figures and costumes in original ways and also relied on the art of his teacher, copying the standing king on the far right almost exactly from a composition by Juárez, though he gave the man a more naturalistic appearance.
Current Location: Figge Art Museum, Davenport, Iowa.
Measurements: 5 ft 1/2 in x 6 ft 5 3/4 in (153.8 x 197.5 cm)

digitalObject.dc:title: Cathedral at Puebla.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Becerra, Francisco, 1545-1605
Gómez de Trasmonte, Juan, -1645?
digitalObject.dc:description: Dedicated by Bishop Juan de Palafox y Mendoza for the Virgin of the Immaculate Conception, this cathedral was meant to be a finer replacement to one finished in the 1530s, one of the earliest cathedrals. Based on a plan by architect Francisco Becerra, this building plan was further enhanced and modified by the involvement of Juan Gómez de Trasmonte. It features the Habsburg coat of arms and its exterior, rather austere, was shaped by the Counter-Reformation rigor of El Escorial, with its severe lines, blocky features, and lack of emphasis on surface ornament (other than the large relief panels, which were common on seventeenth-century Mexico) Location created: Puebla, Mexico.

digitalObject.dc:title: Cathedral of Mexico City.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Arciniega, Claudio de, approximately 1526-1592 or 1593.
digitalObject.dc:description: Based on a plan of 1562 by Claudio Arciniega and inspired by the new cathedral of Jaén in Spain, this cathedral was named the seat of the archbishop in 1541, and thus attained the status of "Metropolitan Cathedral." It has sculptural relief in the center of the facade of the present building shows its patron, the Virgin of the Assumption. The Metropolitan Cathedral is the largest cathedral in the Americas; furthermore, it is situated atop the former Aztec sacred precinct near the Templo Mayor on the northern side of the Plaza de la Constitución in Downtown Mexico City. After the Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire, the conquistadors decided to build their church on the site of the Templo Mayor of the Aztec city of Tenochtitlan to consolidate Spanish power over the newly conquered domain. Hernán Cortés and the other conquistadors used the stones from the destroyed temple of the Aztec god of war Huitzilopochtli, principal deity of the Aztecs, to build the church. It had the Habsburg coat of arms but it was changed after independence, and, like the Cathedral of Puebla, its exterior is also shaped by the Counter-Reformation rigor of El Escorial.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Cathedrals--Mexico--Mexico City.
Church architecture--Mexico--Mexico City.
Church buildings--Mexico--Mexico City.
Architecture--Mexico--Spanish influences.

digitalObject.dc:title: Cathedral of Mexico City.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Arciniega, Claudio de, approximately 1526-1592 or 1593.
digitalObject.dc:description: Based on a plan of 1562 by Claudio Arciniega and inspired by the new cathedral of Jaén in Spain, this cathedral was named the seat of the archbishop in 1541, and thus attained the status of "Metropolitan Cathedral." It has sculptural relief in the center of the facade of the present building shows its patron, the Virgin of the Assumption. The Metropolitan Cathedral is the largest cathedral in the Americas; furthermore, it is situated atop the former Aztec sacred precinct near the Templo Mayor on the northern side of the Plaza de la Constitución in Downtown Mexico City. After the Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire, the conquistadors decided to build their church on the site of the Templo Mayor of the Aztec city of Tenochtitlan to consolidate Spanish power over the newly conquered domain. Hernán Cortés and the other conquistadors used the stones from the destroyed temple of the Aztec god of war Huitzilopochtli, principal deity of the Aztecs, to build the church. It had the Habsburg coat of arms but it was changed after independence, and, like the Cathedral of Puebla, its exterior is also shaped by the Counter-Reformation rigor of El Escorial.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Cathedrals--Mexico--Mexico City.

digitalObject.dc:title: Main Retablo for the Church of Santo Domingo (in situ).
digitalObject.dc:description: Unlike the many facades and altarpieces of the late seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries which preserve the rectilinear architectural framework that had defined the Renaissance period, this retablo has undulating forms with its surface ornamentation seeping into the flat areas above arches and on the column bases and shafts. It also illustrates a denser array of elements--with the painted areas now squeezed out by sculpture--and Solomonic columns, the corkscrew-like forms of which are partly obscured by applied grapevines, as if gilding the lily. In the surviving contract for the altarpiece, the Dominican friars specifically requested that the Mexico City master Pedro Maldonado include these decorated Solomonic columns on the first level, and, on the top story, incorporate a relief of the Nativity taken from the previous 16th century retablo.
Current Location: Church of Santo Domingo, Puebla.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Altarpieces, Baroque--Mexico--Puebla de Zaragoza.

It also illustrates a denser array of elements--with the painted areas now squeezed out by sculpture--and Solomonic columns, the corkscrew-like forms of which are partly obscured by applied grapevines, as if gilding the lily. In the surviving contract for the altarpiece, the Dominican friars specifically requested that the Mexico City master Pedro Maldonado include these decorated Solomonic columns on the first level, and, on the top story, incorporate a relief of the Nativity taken from the previous 16th century retablo.

digitalObject.dc:title: Church of La Soledad.
digitalObject.dcterms:alternative: Basilica of Our Lady of Solitude
digitalObject.dc:description: Carved from soft green stone after a design by a local sculptor named Tomás de Sigüenza, this massive façade has surface decoration that expands up as one looks upwards to the Virgin of the Immaculate Conception which serves as a metaphor for the greater splendors to be found as one approaches heaven. The thick, buttress like facade was created specifically to resist seismic activity as the area of Oaxaca was particularly prone to earthquakes. This is also the reason for the low towers and stunted profiles of the Oaxaca Cathedral.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Church architecture--Mexico--Oaxaca (State)
Cathedrals--Mexico--Oaxaca (State)

digitalObject.dc:title: Church of Santo Domingo.
digitalObject.dc:description: The grey façade of Santo Domingo is an example of severe Herreran classicism, but this gives way to a lavish interior, the walls and ceilings of which are decorated in plaster strapwork, painted and gilded.
